replies.author: @stars-j7g
replies.text: The underbelly of this country never went away. Consider American history, the systemic discrimination founded on racism and colonialism. That never just went away. Just like when mustache man was defeated that ideology didn't just go away either. Things become rebranded over time because the institutions have already previously created them into a feature of our country.

replies.author: @christophergray1673
@AmericaSpeaks1
replies.text:
@pax_aurum_nightlord The world has changed since Carl Stokes became the first Black mayor of a major city (Cleveland, OH). Black mayors have more problems to solve and fewer resources, especially in northern cities. And Lord help a mayor of a blue city in a red state. 
For a lot of mayors, the tax base has moved to the suburbs and there was the crack epidemic and the Republican ‚ÄúWar on Drugs‚Äù and ‚ÄúWar on Crime‚Äù. Not to mention budget constraints that severely hamper even the most progressive mayor‚Äôs agenda.

author: @kenyasmith2652
text:
There‚Äôs a huge lesson in all of this. 

As a Black politician, if you‚Äôre not careful, you can easily get caught up in the power and influence of your White colleagues, just like the Black politicians that were mentioned in the video. 

Also, in this country, when you are a Black politicians, you are basically a Black employee working in a predominantly white workplace, and many of us know how that goes. The only difference is that you get hired by the people who voted for you while regular employees get hired by companies. In order to keep your job and even climb up the ladder, you have to do a whole bunch of butt-kissing, or you won‚Äôt last long. It‚Äôs the same thing with being a Black politician. 

The late Congresswoman Shirley Chisholm is a good example of this. Her campaign focused on improving the lives of Black Americans, and she was part of the Women‚Äôs Liberation Movement. As a result, she didn‚Äôt get a lot of media coverage nor a lot of funding for her presidential campaign. She didn‚Äôt get any endorsements from the National Black Political Convention nor did she get any endorsements from major national women‚Äôs organizations. There were also tensions between Chisholm and the male-dominated Congressional Black Caucus. Now, if Chisolm would have decided to cower down and went along with the game, she probably would have had a better chance of getting nominated for the Democratic Party‚Äôs presidential pick, and this was the early 70s.

replies.author: @stanleyball2615
replies.text: @kenyasmith2652 ( Chisholm took the focus off of Martin Luther King's Federal Government Platform in regards to Education Housing and Employment. It is in the back of his book Where Do We Go From Here? Chaos Or Community? #2 Chisholm took the focus off of the 1972 Gary Indiana Black Independent Platform Convention.. Which was the same year she decided to run for President. Hmmm. #3 Chisholm took the focus off of the Black Panthers Party 10 points Federal Government Platform.

author: @wjpmitchell3
text:
I live in Philly and nearly voted for David Oh because of how far gone Cherrelle Parker was on crime. I reasoned she's probably going to at least be better on sustainable development and labor concerns. Given she's uncritically greenlighting this arena in Chinatown that no one wants and ignoring unions, I legitimately have to wonder how David Oh could have been worse and I've never voted for a Republican in my life.

Edit: she also displaced hundreds if not thousands of homeless and addicted folks from Kensington before any non-police personnel could arrive to aid them. She fed the social workers one time and police a time two hours prior so by the time the social workers could arrive, everyone was scattered. Absolute demon behavior.

replies.text:
My aunt was on the transition committee. A part of her work was to both liason to the older, established leaders and help the mayor navigate the fine line of how to push for change without losing the older gen. They knew if they pushed too hard or offended the wrong person, they'd risk what could be accomplished.

It's hella complicated down there.

replies.author: @bortbenxley6880
replies.text:
‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã@dizzylilthingDC was like 70 percent black through the 70s and 80s and dropped off significantly due to gentrification and displacement after the year 2000. I was born in the 90's and raised there, feel like I got to see some of the last years before it changed so much. People got displaced as the city leadership courted developers and gentrifiers at the direct expense of poor natives. The Chocolate City name still sticks in account of the history, but the city has truly changed. 

Also I'ma add, "Fuck Muriel Bowser, all my Homies hate Muriel Bowser."in

replies.author: @djslarge
replies.text:
@dizzylilthingyes, DC in the 1980s, was the blackest city in the US, even now, it‚Äôs still black majority
DC is an urban area and while Capitol Hill, Georgetown, and Chevy Chase are very suburban and white, that‚Äôs only 10% of the city, with the rest being very urban and very colored

author: @momi1610
text: Olay, you are truly beloved. The work that you do to inform everyone -- but particularly Black people -- is supremely commendable. Selfishly, I am glad that you've decided to hang in there and continue your great work as a communicator and freedom fighter in the U.S. I know that you've been faced with unnecessary negatively on-and- offline. I would've understood if you would've bowed out and focused squarely on your own well-being. But I am glad that you do see that in the middle of all of that noise, there is genuine praise and appreciation. The way that you see ALL Black people, even though many of us don't do the same in return for you, is....  I don't even have the proper words.... Other than to state that, when it's time for you to enter the pearly gates, a long shimmery red carpet will be rolled out divinely in your honor.

author: @AlexsGoogleAccount
text:
Thank you for breaking this down in a thoughtful way.

Our major has been expanding police surveillance, putting thousands of new cameras in the city and expanding gunshot detection technology that we know is placed in poor neighborhoods and has high rates of false alarms and nobody around me seems to care.

I am concerned that there will be severe abuses of this heavy surveillance once AI gets incorporated, and of course despite running as a black progressive, our mayor has only increased the police budget.

I've been trying to understand why this is happening and why people don't seem to care.

author: @Crobin008
text: Being someone from Philly, Mayor Parker continues to ignore and alienate the people she is suppose to represent, the stop and fisk wasn't the move. Nor was the window tint bill she had passed. Her 'attempt' at cleaning up Kensington did nothing but effect surrounding families in the neighborhood when the drug dealers and homeless addicts started to make encampments on their blocks, disturbing their peace and not actually attacking the problem. She eliminate hybrid scheduling/the ability to work from home for city employees (while acting as if she didn't want to renegotiate with the union in a collective bargaining agreement)  and she's putting pressure on other business companies, privately owned companies, to follow suit and eliminate hybrid scheduling for their employees all to get people to spend money in a section of the city she was trying to RUIN!!!! by supporting a billionaires' bid to put a new basketball stadium on market street...goofy ass getting cussed out at town halls while trying to defend the idea of a stadium at market east... Ignoring the fact that Jefferson , Septa, Chinatown and many other groups and citizens stated valid, sensible reasons why the stadium would be a bad idea..how it would cripple center city. City council didn't stand on business, sided with the mayor in three consecutive 12-5 votes...only to look foolish when the billionaire used her and her council as leverage to get a new deal with Comcast and abandon plans to build the stadium down town ....Comes out in a press conference, like we are stupid, spinning it as if it was apart of her plan all along............yo.........I know she isn't the worse mayor of all time in this city but she is certainly making a case to be top 5 in history

author: @paintedporpoise
text:
Fun fact about sloths.

Their primary cause of death is pooping.

The majority of their lives they live up in the trees chillin not a care in the world munching on leaves and shit.

BUT about once a month they have to poop, their digestive system is so slow that it takes a month and the effort of doing so is so great they cannot remain dangling from the trees whilst doing so.

When they come down to the ground they are most vulnerable to the big cats in the jungle that are their primary predator

author: @abraxasjinx5207
text:
Thank you for giving us all so much wisdom! Another YouTube creator that meant so much to me ended up coming very close to burning out and had to step aside. He had the foresight to see that if he didn't take a step back, he was going to collapse. He has been wise enough to have his wife take over the speaking/filming part of their channel, and has gone more towards the background work that they as a couple and their full support team do. 

Hearing your words at the end of the video, I want to make sure you're putting on your own air mask before you try to save anyone else who is going down in this plane crash. 

I was not wise in my personal care, and the election results broke me. Even though I knew I was beginning to get overwhelmed and knew I needed to improve my self-care, I didn't put in enough personal time and work to prepare, and I hit a wall badly on November 6. 

You know that you are greatly appreciated and you have a loving community. Please take care and don't ask more from yourself than is feasible. I only just found your channel, but have been so grateful for everything you have to say. As much urgency as we are all feeling right now, take your work at a  sustainable pace. 
üíúüñ§ü§ç‚ô•Ô∏è
